docs.lead_paragraph: There are health books galore for women of every age -- almost. Despite a wealth of books dealing with pregnancy, menopause and virtually every disease, few medical guides deal with the crucial needs of schoolgirls, according to Sharon L. Roan, a medical writer. So Ms. Roan decided to fill the gap. Her informative and inspiring new book, ''Our Daughters' Health: Practical and Invaluable Advice for Raising Confident Girls Ages 6-16,'' is full of practical strategies to make young girls health-conscious.

headline.main: Learning How to Teach Your Daughters Well

docs.abstract: Randi Hutter Epstein reviews Sharon L Roan book Our Daughters' Health: Practical and Invaluable Advice for Raising Confident Girls Ages 6-16; photo (M)
docs.snippet: There are health books galore for women of every age -- almost. Despite a wealth of books dealing with pregnancy, menopause and virtually every disease, few medical guides deal with the crucial needs of schoolgirls, according to Sharon L. Roan, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Heavy users of methamphetamine -- a highly addictive stimulant that can be made at home in the kitchen sink -- are doing more damage to their brains than scientists had thought, according to the first study that looked inside addicts' brains nearly a year after they stopped using the drug. At least a quarter of a class of molecules that help people feel pleasure and reward were knocked out by methamphetamine, the study found. Some of the addicts' brains resembled those of people with early and mild Parkinson's disease. But the biggest surprise is that another brain region responsible for spatial perception and sensation, which has never before been linked to methamphetamine abuse, was hyperactive and showed signs of scarring.

headline.main: Drug's Effect On Brain Is Extensive, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study finds extensive damage to brains of methamphetamine addicts nearly a year after they stop using drug; drug appears to diminish dopamine levels, which help people feel pleasure and reward, make some addicts' brains resemble those of people with early and mild Parkinson's disease and cause hyperactivity and signs of scarring in brain region responsible for spacial perception and sensation; addicts also did worse than nonaddicts on tests of memory, attention and movement (M)
docs.snippet: Heavy users of methamphetamine -- a highly addictive stimulant that can be made at home in the kitchen sink -- are doing more damage to their brains than scientists had thought, according to the first study that looked inside addicts' brains nearly a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Coronary bypass surgery to circumvent clogged arteries that feed the heart has, since its inception in the 1960's, brought relief from crippling chest pain and significantly prolonged life for millions of people. But as dozens of studies have shown, despite major improvements in technique, better selection of patients and highly experienced cardiac surgeons, bypass surgery is still hardly an innocuous procedure. It is associated with a mortality rate of 1 percent to 2 percent; some patients suffer surgery-related strokes, and in the years that follow, as many as half of bypassed vessels themselves become clogged, requiring another bypass or some other procedure to restore adequate coronary blood flow.

headline.main: Now, Choices in Heart Bypass Surgery

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on advances in coronary bypass surgery, which since its inception in 1960's has brought relief from crippling chest pain and significantly prolonged life for millions of people; notes hazards of procedure, including possibility of mental decline; points out that experts say many patients who now undergo bypass surgery could benefit just as much from a less risky and less debilitating procedure: angioplasty to widen opening of clogged vessels and insertion of stents to keep them open; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes people buttonhole Dr. Charles H. Clark Jr. at professional meetings and hint that he might do well to muzzle his most high-profile employee, Dr. Sally Satel. ''Can't you control Sally?'' they ask.

headline.main: A Critic Takes On Psychiatric Dogma, Loudly

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Sally Satel, psychiatrist who has generated controversy with her writing on topics like drug addiction, mental health policies and what she calls political correctness in medicine; she insists that addiction is fundamentally a problem of behavior over which addicts have voluntary control, criticizes public health researchers for focusing on racism and poverty rather than health education and disease-fighting strategies, criticizes feminists for construing wife-battering as symptom of patriarchal society and argues that psychiatry is being co-opted by culture of 'victimology'; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Sometimes people buttonhole Dr. Charles H. Clark Jr. at professional meetings and hint that he might do well to muzzle his most high-profile employee, Dr. Sally Satel.    ''Can't you control Sally?'' they ask.
